sentence: The Dow and S&P 500 closed fractionally lower on Tuesday as accusations against President Donald Trump regarding dissemination of classified material weighed on investor confidence.
The Nasdaq, however, closed higher for a ninth consecutive day as strength in the technology sector pushed the index to a second consecutive record close.
The major market averages all opened higher despite early weakness tied to a Washington Post story alleging Trump shared confidential information with the Russian foreign minister.
The news weighed on the dollar, driving the euro to its highest level against the dollar in more than six months, and wiping out all the post-election gains in the dollar index.

Soft housing market data contributed to a slight pull-back in premarket trading , but equities bounced back as industrial production posted its strongest one-month gain since Feb 2014, and capacity utilization hit 76.7%, both of which exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

After the open, the administration's attempt at damage control caused widespread selling pressure as concerns about Trump's ability to enact pro-growth legislation in the current atmosphere continued to plague Wall Street.
And although the Nasdaq made an impressive comeback, the Dow and S&P 500 clung to the flatline for the remainder of the session.
In corporate news, Ford ( F ) said it would cut 10% of its white-collar workforce in North America and Asia in an effort to "become as lean and efficient as possible."

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(-) ETRM (-28.20%) Reported a loss of $1.27 per share on 43% drop in revenue
